title: AB 1228
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to support foster care agencies by providing information on admissions requirements and financial aid to California's higher education institutions. Additionally, they urge the University of California and California State University to consider using admissions-by-exemption to help homeless and foster youth transition into four-year public colleges. Section 76010 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize housing for current and former homeless youth and foster youth at California Community Colleges. Housing facilities open year-round are to be provided at no extra cost during breaks, with first priority given to these students. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is required to develop a plan to ensure housing resources for current and former homeless youth and foster youth, regardless of student housing facilities. A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years old verified as homeless within the past 24 months by specific entities. The Education Code is amended to include provisions for housing resources for homeless youth and foster youth. A student verified as a former homeless youth retains that status for six years from admission. Section 90001.5 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing at California State University campuses, providing them with stable housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. Each campus of the California State University is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed during academic terms and breaks, regardless of student housing availability. A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years of age who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by specific entities. The director of federal TRIO or Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs program, a financial aid administrator, and a verified former homeless youth shall retain their status for six years. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended to prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for student housing at University of California campuses, providing them with stable housing at no extra cost during academic breaks. The University of California is requested to develop a plan to ensure that homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources during academic breaks. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years of age who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. The section specifies who can verify a student as a former homeless youth and how long that status lasts. It also clarifies that the University of California is not subject to this section unless the Regents choose to make it applicable.
